page.title: 13Local History of Kingswood.
page.content: Kingswood derives its name from the Royal Forest or King's Wood which covered much of southern England before the reign of King Henry III. During the{industrial revolution}the area was extensively mined for coal.{ {William Champion,}a Quaker and industrialist, built the first commercial{zinc}plant in Europe in Warmley in 1746. He built cottages for his workers with several shops and a clocktower.In the mid 18th century the {Cockroad Road gang}were a notorious band of theives who dominated a hive of criminal activity. Both{George {Whitfield and John Wesley}regularly preached to the people of Kingswood, and there is a symbolic beacon on Hanham Mount in memory of preachers who were persecuted and put to death.{ {Whitfield's Tabernacle}was built in 1741 during the{religious revival.
